data.title: Haim Saban
data.meta_description: The billionaire investor is planning a big change to his portfolio with the decision to put Univision Communications on the block. Saban and a consortium of private-equity firms have owned the Spanish-language TV giant since 2007. The company has struggled in recent years amid the broader upheaval in television and changing tastes among Univision’s target […]
data.text:
The billionaire investor is planning a big change to his portfolio with the decision to put Univision Communications on the block. Saban and a consortium of private-equity firms have owned the Spanish-language TV giant since 2007. The company has struggled in recent years amid the broader upheaval in television and changing tastes among Univision’s target audience. Separately, Saban Capital Group is an active investor in media and related businesses. He most recently committed $500 million to the launch of Saban Music Group after acquiring Gustavo Lopez’s Talento Uno Music. That venture marks a return to Saban’s roots as a musician in Israel, before he hit it big in the 1990s as the producer of “The Mighty Morphin Power Rangers.”

Static and Ben El, the pop music duo from Israel whose success in their home country led to a rich deal with Saban Music Group (via Virgin), has called it quits after seven years together. Backed by American-Israeli entertainment mogul Haim Saban, the group hit the ground running in 2018 with the English-language version of “Tudo Bom,” a bouncy Reggaeton track featuring J. Balvin. “Dear Friends – this was not an easy decision, however the duo known as Static and...
